journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part P: Journal of Sports Engineering and Technology

title-group.article-title: A unified framework for the prediction of cricket ball trajectories in spin and swing bowling

contrib-group.aff: School of Civil Engineering, University of Birmingham, UK

author-notes.corresp: Chris Baker, School of Civil Engineering, University of Birmingham, Edgbaston, Birmingham B15 2TT, UK. Email: c.j.baker@bham.ac.uk

abstract.p: This paper builds on earlier work of the author that calculated the trajectories of cricket balls under fast swing bowling conditions, and develops a unified analytical framework for the consideration of both slow spin bowling and fast swing bowling. A classification of different types of bowling delivery, in so far as they relate to the flight of the ball through the air, is set out, and from this classification four generic cases of seam and spin plane angle are identified for further consideration. The force coefficient characteristics on spinning balls due to auto-rotational effects (due to the spin of the ball) are then derived, and these are used to develop the full equations of motion that can predict both swing and spin bowling trajectories. The four generic cases are then investigated using approximate solutions of these equations, the trajectories of spin bowling in lateral and vertical directions are explored and the relative magnitudes of flight displacements due to the boundary layer asymmetry (the cause of swing bowling displacements) and auto-rotational forces are discussed. Finally, the effects of cross winds on spin bowling trajectories are considered. In summary the paper presents an overall methodology that enables the various flow phenomenon associated with cricket ball flight to be considered in a unified manner.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In a recent paper1 the author has presented a method for calculating the trajectories of cricket balls when bowled by swing bowlers. This mode of bowling, with the seam of the ball held at an angle to the direction of movement, results in an asymmetric flow separation around the ball which, in turn, results in a force perpendicular to the direction of travel and thus a lateral movement as the ball moves from the bowler to the batsman (see Mehta,2 Sayers3 and Brouy et al.4 for recent work in this area). In that paper1 the author fully described the calculation, set out the full equations of motion and, through a consideration of the work of earlier authors, developed a number of generic lateral force coefficient characteristics that relate the side force coefficient to the Reynolds number and display different types of transition between the sub- and super-critical Reynolds number regimes. The author then used these characteristics to solve the equations of motion to calculate ball trajectories for a variety of conditions and showed that quite complex trajectories can be predicted, particularly when the Reynolds number is within the transition range. The author also derived an approximate form of solution that is shown to have little error for the cases where the Reynolds number throughout the flight remains sub- or supercritical and does not enter the transition range. This analysis enables an understanding to be gained of the main physical phenomena that affect the lateral swing of cricket balls, in particular highlighting the importance of the parameter known as the Tachikawa number and the side force coefficient and allowing the effects of crosswinds to be quantified.

Swing bowling requires a fairly high initial speed of the ball as delivered by the bowler – of the order of 70 mile/h or above (corresponding to a Reynolds number based on ball diameter of around 1.5 × 105).5 At lower bowling speeds a different form of bowling is often utilised – spin bowling in which the ball is spun rapidly by the bowler either through a finger or a wrist action.5 The Reynolds number for such bowling is usually around 0.5 to 1.0 × 105. The main purpose of imparting such spin is to change the direction of bounce of the ball close to the batsman. However, it is well known in the cricket fraternity that spin can also induce a deviation of the flight of the ball from its expected path in both horizontal and vertical directions (‘drift’ and ‘dip’). This is due to what is often described as the Magnus effect, where the relative velocity of the air to the ball is different on each side of the spin plane due to the spin itself, which creates a differential pressure across the ball. There is some confusion of nomenclature here, as the Magnus effect is often taken to refer to an inviscid flow phenomenon, whereas the Reynolds number for spin bowling is such that boundary layer separation and wake formation will occur. It is nonetheless widely used.

This paper investigates the movement of balls through the air in spin bowling more fully. In particular the application of the methodology of the author’s earlier paper to this type of bowling is considered.1 The interaction between the mechanisms responsible for the movements of balls in the air in swing and spin bowling is also investigated and a general framework derived for the consideration of the flight of cricket balls throughout the likely bowling speed range is presented. The work follows on from the earlier work1 for seam bowling, and the reader is referred to that paper for a discussion of the background literature on seam bowling at the higher bowling speeds. In ‘The classification of bowling types’, a systematic classification of the movement of balls through the air for different types of bowling is presented, which is used to define the limits of the study that follow. ‘Aerodynamic forces on a swinging and spinning cricket ball’ then considers the overall forces on a cricket ball due to the flow mechanisms that control both the swing and spin phenomena, and sets out the equations of motion. An approximate analysis is then developed in ‘Approximate solution and trajectory calculations’ which gives a clear physical insight into the nature of the ball movement and presents some analytical and numerical results for ball trajectories. Finally, some concluding remarks are made in ‘Conclusions’.

sec.title: The classification of bowling types
sec.p: Even a cursory reading of the literature will reveal that there are a very wide range of names of different bowling types and delivery styles within the game of cricket. However, in general, it is possible to define three main styles.

list-item.p: Swing bowling (SB) where the ball is bowled at speeds of 65 mph and above, and the ball moves laterally through the air due to the asymmetric flow on either side of the ball, caused by the position of the seam and the relative roughness of the two sides of the ball. The ball can also be made to deviate slightly on bouncing in certain bowling styles.
Finger spinning (FS) where the ball is spun by a finger action, resulting in movement through the air and a sharp deviation when the ball bounces.
Wrist spinning (WS) where the ball is spun by a combined finger and wrist action, again resulting in movement through the air and deviation on bouncing.

sec.p: It will be shown below that essentially the aerodynamic forces on the ball are due to three parameters.

list-item.p: The angle α of the spin plane to the ball direction of travel. In most bowling types the spin axis is perpendicular to the plane of the seam of the ball and thus spin is around the seam. In what follows α =0 will be when the seam is pointing in the direction of travel.
The angle β of the spin plane to the vertical. β =0 will be taken when the spin plane is vertical.

The rate and direction of spin of the ball – this can either be topspin (T) when the top of the ball is spinning in the direction of travel, and thus the relative air flow over the top of the ball is faster than the speed of the ball, or backspin (B) when the top of the ball is moving in the opposite direction.

sec.p: In attempting to classify the different types of bowling in terms of the above parameters, two sources in particular were used.

list-item.p: Various Wikipedia articles.5 Clearly the rather unreliable nature of the sources must be acknowledged, but these articles do seem to represent the best collation of information available, although as might be expected, some of this is self contradictory and inconsistent – partly as a result that cricketers in different parts of the world use different terminology for the same type of delivery.
A number of training videos6 that do enable precise inspection of ball trajectory for different bowling types.

sec.p: From this information it is clear that for the large majority of bowling types, the angle β is close to zero (within 10 or 20°), that is, the seam is close to the vertical. For such situations one can thus classify bowling types within the α-spin rate plane as shown in Table 1 below.

caption.p: Types of bowling for vertical spin plane β=0° (note that the values of α that are given should only be regarded as approximate).

fn.p: SB: swing bowling; WS: wrist spinning; FS: finger spinning.

sec.p: It should be emphasised that the above classification is based on movement through the air and does not take account of deviation on bouncing. Inswingers, outswingers and reverse swing deliveries were studied,1 and represent the main mode of bowling of medium and fast swing bowlers. Leg breaks and Googlies are the major types of delivery of wrist spinners. In addition a number of different types of delivery for small values of α are bowled by finger spinners and wrist spinners with varying types and degrees of spin. Not all important deliveries are bowled with the spin plane vertical however, and these are shown in Table 2.

caption.p: Types of delivery for a non-vertical spin plane.

tr.th: Anti-clockwise spin as seen by bowler
Clockwise spin as seen by bowler

tr.td: α = 0°, β = 90° (seam horizontal and pointing into the flow, spin and seam planes coincide)
α = 90°, β = 0° (seam vertical and pointing into the flow, spin plane perpendicular to seam plane)

fn.p: SB: swing bowling; FS: finger spinning.

sec.p: Off breaks and Doosras are the main balls bowled by finger spinners, whilst leg cutters and off cutters are bowled by medium to fast swing bowlers, with the primary intention of inducing direction change as the ball bounces, rather than influencing the flight of the ball.

It is unlikely that the above classification will meet with anything like universal agreement within the wider cricketing community, and there are of course many variations about the types of bowling set out above, with subtle variations in the angles of the spin plane to the direction of flight and to the vertical, depending on bowling style and preference. However, the results of Tables 1 and 2 do give a useful framework to define the parameters that will be investigated in this paper. Specifically, the following cases will be investigated.

list-item.p: Case 1. α = 0° and β = 0° for a range of spin rates (negative for topspin and positive for backspin). From Table 1 it can be seen that this applies to a number of different types of delivery for finger spin and wrist spin bowlers. The change in vertical trajectory for different spin rates and directions will be investigated.

Case 2. α = ±20° (approx) and β = 0°. This represents the basic delivery for wrist and finger spinners. As the spin plane is vertical, it will be shown below that the effect of spin will largely be in the vertical plane and identical to the α = 0° and β = 0° cases considered above. However, there will also be lateral forces on the ball due to boundary layer asymmetry, and the relative magnitudes of the vertical and lateral displacements for different ball speeds and spin rates will be investigated.

Case 3. α = 0°, β = 90°, which represents the basic delivery for finger spinners. As the spin plane is horizontal, the aerodynamic force due to the spin will be in a lateral direction, but as the spin plane and the seam faces into the flow, there will be no forces on the ball due to boundary layer asymmetry, either laterally or vertically.
Case 4. α = 0°, β = 90°, as in case 3, but with the addition of a small cross wind

sec.title: Aerodynamic forces on a swinging and spinning cricket ball
Aerodynamic forces on cricket balls
sec.p: The aerodynamic forces on a cricket ball that has an asymmetric boundary layer flow over its surface and is also spinning can be classified as three distinct types – an aerodynamic drag in the opposite direction to the flight of the ball, an aerodynamic side force that acts laterally to the flight direction due to boundary layer asymmetry, and a force due to the spinning motion of the ball that acts in the plane of spin perpendicular to the direction of travel. These will be considered in turn below. Note that it will be implicitly assumed that these flow mechanisms are independent which cannot of course be strictly true, but must serve as a working assumption in the lack of any deeper knowledge of such interactions.

sec.title: Aerodynamic drag force
sec.p:
The aerodynamic drag force, D, acts opposite to the direction of travel of the ball, and is usually characterised by the drag coefficient,
C
D

where A is the ball cross sectional area, ρ is the density of air and Q is the total air velocity relative to the ball. The drag coefficient is a function of Reynolds number (which from now on will be defined as Re =ρqd/µ, where d is the ball diameter, q is the initial bowling speed and µ is the dynamic viscosity of air. To a reasonable approximation, the drag coefficient can be taken to have constant values for Reynolds numbers above and below the boundary layer transition value (around 2 × 105). For spin bowling the Reynolds number will be in the range of 105 to 1.5 × 105, that is, in the sub-critical range.

sec.title: Aerodynamic side force
sec.p:
The side force on the ball due to boundary layer asymmetry, S, which always acts perpendicular to the direction of flight. It is characterised by the side force coefficient,
C
S

The nature of the parameter was discussed in earlier work,1 and generic side force characteristics derived for balls of different types from a range of published sources. Essentially it was assumed that the side force coefficient was constant in the sub- and supercritical ranges. The experimental data suggested some effect of spin, although the data was inconsistent and uncertain in this regard, and also that the side force coefficient fell to zero for low Reynolds numbers of around 0.5 × 105.

sec.title: Auto-rotational force
sec.p:
The auto-rotational force F due to the spin of the ball always acts in the plane of spin perpendicular to the relative air velocity in the spin plane. This force is due to an induced pressure difference across the ball in the plane of spin caused by the different velocities near the ball surface on the two sides of the ball (approximately the ball velocity in the plane of spin plus the spin velocity of the ball surface on one side, and the ball velocity minus the spin velocity of the surface on the other). If the ball is spun such that the top of the ball is moving in the direction of travel (topspin), then the force will be downwards in the vertical direction. Potential flow calculations for a cylinder spinning with an angular velocity
ω
in a flow of velocity V gives the force per unit length of the cylinder as

The questions then arise as to, firstly, the adequacy of the assumption of equation (1), i.e. that the drag coefficient does not vary with spin rate and that the auto-rotational force coefficient is proportional to
ω
¯
and, secondly, the value of the parameter a. A number of sets of experimental results exist that are useful in this regard.

list-item.p:
Sayers and Hill7 report measurements of drag and auto-rotational force coefficients for cricket balls with the spin plane parallel to the flow, that is, α = β = 0. Spin rates up to 1000 r/min, which corresponds to 16.7 r/s, or a value of
ω
¯
of between 0.25 and 0.37 for a value of d of 0.071 m and bowling speeds, q, of between 20 and 30 m/s. This spin rate is probably above the upper level of what is actually achievable in the spin bowling process. The small scale of the figures in Sayers and Hill,7 and the fact that they are presented in a dimensional rather than a dimensionless form, makes them difficult to accurately transcribe, but they will nonetheless be used in what follows.

Nathan8 gives a compilation of the results of other authors for baseballs, mainly at spin rates significantly higher than those achievable in the bowling of a cricket ball (values of
ω
¯
up to 2.0), over a wide range of Reynolds numbers. However, there is some information at the lower spin rates that is of use.

Carre et al.9 give a compilation of data for footballs at values of
ω
¯
up to around 1.0, over a range of Reynolds numbers spanning the transition between sub- and supercritical flows.

sec.p:
Consider first the drag coefficients. The results of Sayers and Hill7 for cricket balls suggests that over a Reynolds number range from 0.97 to 1.46 × 105, and values
ω
¯
between 0.15 and 0.25 the drag coefficient is between 0.32 and 0.37, although the precise values cannot be determined because of the difficulties of transcribing the experimental data. The data of Carre et al.9 for footballs again shows little dependence upon
ω
¯
but vary somewhat with Reynolds number – from around 0.2 at Re = 2.1 × 105, to around 0.3 at 1.1 × 105, which is clearly in the transition range for such balls. On the basis of this rather limited set of data, the assumption of constant drag coefficient as the spin rate varies seems justified. With regard to the auto-rotational force coefficient, Figure 1 shows a compilation of the data of Sayers and Hill,7 Nathan8 and Carre et al.9 for
ω
¯
< 0 . 4
, over a range of Reynolds numbers for baseballs, cricket balls and footballs. In general, there can be seen to be the expected increase in coefficient with
ω
¯
, although there is very considerable scatter in the data. There is some indication of a variation with Reynolds number, particularly for the football data with an increase in the coefficients for an increase in Reynolds number. The reverse seems to be true for the cricket balls, although the likely errors in the results of Sayers and Hill7 need to be borne in mind once again. On the basis of this data, however, there seems no reason for assuming anything other than a linear variation of auto-rotational force coefficient with
ω
¯
, with values of a between 0.5 and 1.0. Clearly further experimental work would be required to obtain more precise values for a range of cricket balls.

caption.p: Auto-rotational force coefficients (cricket ball data is from Sayers and Hill,7 baseball data from Nathan8 and football data from Carre et al.9).

sec.title: Equations of motion
sec.p: Applying Newton’s Law in the x, y and z directions and suitably non-dimensionalising, one obtains the basic trajectory equations for the flight of cricket balls taking into account the three different types of force outlined above, and also allowing for the presence of a cross wind

These equations are derived from those developed by the author for the flight of wind borne debris,10 that have been used to both understand the mechanics of debris flight, but also to investigate problems such as leaf flight and ballast flight around and under high speed trains.11 Here

. T is the Tachikawa number given by

where m is the mass of the ball.

is the non-dimensional cross wind velocity V/q, where V is the wind speed which is assumed to be constant with height and acting directly across the pitch.

sec.title: Approximate solution and trajectory calculations
sec.p: In earlier work1 the author developed some approximate solutions of the equations of motion for seam bowling, and a comparison with the numerical solutions of the full equations showed them to be very accurate for conditions in which the force coefficients were invariant with Reynolds number (i.e. the sub- and supercritical flow regimes). Importantly these solutions gave an insight into the important parameters of the problem. Since for spin bowling the force coefficients can also be expected to be invariant with Reynolds number, this approach will be adopted here. It can easily be shown that the approximate solutions that will be obtained are once again very close to the full numerical solutions of the equations of motion, and again their utility is that the consideration of such solutions enables a physical insight into the problem to be obtained. In what follows it will be assumed that:

list-item.p:
the lateral and vertical ball velocities are much smaller than the longitudinal velocities, that is,

the angles α and β do not change throughout the flight (which implies that the displacement in the x direction is much greater than the displacements in the y and z directions).

sec.p: Making these assumptions, the four cases outlined in ‘The classification of bowling types’ are then considered. Table 3 shows, for each case, the equations of motion in the three directions, the variation of the three components of velocity with time, the variation of the three distances from the point of release with time, and the x–y (horizontal) and x–z (vertical) trajectories. The latter are calculated on the assumption that the product CDT is much less than unity, which can be shown to be generally true.1

caption.p: Equations of motion and their solutions.

tr.th: Case 4 α = 0°, β = 90° with cross wind

sec.p:
For case 1, with the spin plane vertical and pointing into the flow, there is no lateral deviation as expected, and the vertical deviation from the simple gravity driven acceleration takes on a parabolic form and is proportional to
a
ω

T

2
. Specific trajectories are plotted in Figure 2. In the calculations of these trajectories it is assumed that a = 1.0 and that the initial angle of flight of the ball to the horizontal is chosen such that it bounces on the ground (assumed to be at z = –2.0 m) at 18 m from the bowling position. It can be seen that for the positive spin case (defined in this case as backspin) the trajectory is above the gravity driven case, and the reverse is true for the negative spin case (topspin). This is as expected with topspin known to make the ball ‘dip’ during its trajectory and vice versa. The differences in the actual flight paths are significant, with the landing position varying by around 3 m for identical bowling conditions, except for the spin being in opposite directions.

caption.p:
Vertical trajectories for different spin rates (Case 1 –α=β = 0°, q = 40 mph,

sec.p:
Case 2 is similar to case 1, except that the seam is now at an angle to the flow and boundary layer asymmetry effects will cause a lateral movement. The ratio of the vertical deviation from the gravity driven trajectory to the lateral deviation in this case is

. This implies that as the bowling speed, q, decreases, the vertical deviation due to spin becomes much larger than the lateral deviation due to flow asymmetry. Conversely as the bowling speed increases, the effects of spin become less important.

Case 3 is for the case of a horizontal spin plane, with the plane in the direction of the flow. For this case, one would only expect lateral aerodynamic forces. Thus not surprisingly the vertical trajectory does not deviate from the gravity driven form. The lateral deviation is given by

, which is similar to the parabolic form identified for swing bowling.1 In dimensional terms the deviation, y, is proportional to ω/q and, thus, it can be seen that the spin induced lateral deviation will decrease as the bowling velocity is increased. Typical trajectories are shown in Figure 3.

sec.p:
Case 4 is for a similar situation to case 3, but with the effect of a constant cross wind added. From Table 3 it can be seen that the ratio of the wind induced deflection to spin induced deflection is
C
D
V
¯
/ a
ω
¯
, or in dimensional terms
V
C
D
/ a ω d
. For a = 1.0, ω= 5 r/s, V = 2 m/s (an average velocity near the ground) and CD = 0.5, this ratio has the value of 0.45, and thus the displacement due to wind is significant in terms of the displacement due to spin. However, whilst to a first approximation the wind velocity might be constant during the time it takes for a delivery to travel from one end of the pitch to the other, it might vary substantially between deliveries. If the turbulence intensity is 0.25, a typical value of near ground conditions, for a 2 m/s mean wind speed, for standard deviation of the wind speed will be ±0.5 m/s – and thus 95% of all realisations of wind speed over the course of the delivery will be between 2 ±1 m/s. Thus, the ratio of the wind displacement to the spin displacement can vary between approximately 0.22 and 0.9. Such variability could make batting conditions difficult under such circumstances.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: From what has been written above the following conclusions can be drawn.

list-item.p: It is possible to map most types of cricket swing and seam bowling in terms of spin plane angle to the direction of flight, spin plane angle to the vertical and spin rate. This allows the nature of the aerodynamic forces to be appreciated in a broad context.

The auto-rotational forces on the ball will always act in the spin plane perpendicular to the direction of flight. A collation of previous experimental data enables a dimensionless equation to be derived for the auto-rotational force coefficients in terms of the dimensionless spin rate.
The equations of motion of cricket ball flight developed in earlier work1 can be extended to take account of the auto-rotation effects.
Incorporation of the auto-rotational forces allows the occurrence of dip and drift to be demonstrated for spin bowling, and allows the auto-rotational deflections to be quantified.
It is shown that under certain circumstances both auto-rotational forces and lateral forces due to boundary layer asymmetry can exist, with both vertical and lateral deflections of the ball.

In reasonably strong, but by no means exceptional, winds, the wind-induced cross wind forces can be significant when compared with the auto-rotational forces, and there is the possibility that the random, unsteady nature of near ground wind conditions can result in conditions where the movement of the ball through the air due to auto-rotational forces is far from predictable.
